title: How to Move to Los Angeles

steps.headline: Set a monthly budget for yourself so you know how much you can spend.
steps.description: Write down the cost of your current expenses to see how much you’re regularly spending on rent, utilities, groceries, and other recurring charges. Compare the amount that you spend to your current income to see how much money you’re able to comfortably spend each month. Determine what you can afford per month for rent so you can start looking for places in LA. The average rent in LA is usually around $1,000-1,300 per person depending on what neighborhood you choose to live in. Try to save up at least 3 times your monthly expenses before you move to LA in case you aren’t able to find a job immediately. That way, you can still afford your costs of living.

steps.headline: Pick a neighborhood in the city that’s safe and affordable.
steps.description: Los Angeles is a large, sprawling city broken up into multiple neighborhoods. Look at a map of LA online so you can see where each neighborhood is in the city. Check for restaurants and locations in the neighborhoods that interest you so you know what you’ll be close to. Write down a few different neighborhoods where you want to live so you can search for places in the area. If you want to be near the ocean, then look in neighborhoods like Venice or Manhattan Beach. For a more traditional big city living, choose to look Downtown for places to live. If you want a safe area with lots of things to do, try looking in Silver Lake or Glendale. Choose places in the Valley, like Studio City or Burbank, to be close to the entertainment industry. Areas like Chesterfield Square and Compton are less safe than other neighborhoods to the north. EXPERT TIP																															Hannah Park																Real Estate Agent								Hannah Park is a Licensed Real Estate Agent operating in Los Angeles, California and is a part of Keller Williams, Larchmont. She received her Real Estate Certification in 2018 from the California Bureau of Real Estate, and now specializes as a Buyer's Agent and Listing Agent. Hannah Park			Real Estate Agent				Get a real estate agent that is knowledgeable in the greater Los Angeles area. They can give you a good idea of areas in your price range. Even better, if you know what area you are looking for, find a realtor that has a niche in that particular area.

steps.headline: Check for home listings online to see what areas are available.
steps.description: Search on real estate websites to look for a home you can either buy or rent and save any that are in your budget and look comfortable. If you can’t find anything on the real estate websites, try browsing through Craigslist to see what homes and apartments are available. When you find homes you like, save them and contact the landlord or owner as soon as you can to set up a showing and learn more about the property. Prices for housing will vary depending on the neighborhood you choose. For example, apartments in Manhattan Beach may be over $2,000 USD a month per person, but a similar one may only cost $1,300 USD per person in Palms. Modest homes usually cost around $800,000 USD, which includes 2 bedrooms, a bathroom, a kitchen, and a living space.Tip: Check what utilities and appliances are included with the rent price since you may have to pay them separately. For example, many apartments in Los Angeles don’t include a fridge in the cost of rent.

steps.headline: Try finding a roommate to split the cost of living.
steps.description: It can be difficult to find a 1-bedroom apartment that’s within your budget, but 2-bedroom apartments are much more common. Reach out to people you may already know in the city or search Craigslist for people that you could share a place with. Reach out to the individual people and try to meet them in person before choosing to live with them. If you have another friend that’s interested in moving to LA, see if they want to be your roommate so you can cut your expenses in half. Be wary of online posts that feel like spam or don’t offer a lot of details.

steps.headline: Visit the places that you’re interested in to get a feel for the space and location.
steps.description: Plan a trip to LA if you’re able to so you can tour the apartments or homes that you’re interested in. Walk through the building and look for any signs of damage or concern that you have. Ask questions about the neighborhood, policies the building has, previous owners or tenants, and what’s included with your rent payment. Don’t settle on the first place you see since you may be able to get a better deal somewhere else. If you’re not able to visit a location in person, ask a friend in the area to look at the location for you and take pictures so you can get a better look before moving.

steps.headline: Rent or buy the place where you want to live.
steps.description: Once you find a place where you want to live, fill out the application form or make an offer on the home. Once your application or offer is accepted, read through any paperwork you have so you know the terms and conditions before signing it. Either make your down payment or security deposit before moving in and getting keys. The security deposit for your place is usually the same cost as 1 month’s rent, but it may be more depending on your work history or neighborhood.

steps.headline: Pack only the items you need to save on moving costs.
steps.description: Take enough clothes in your luggage so you can have a fresh outfit each day until the rest of your items arrive. Keep documents, like your Social Security card or birth certificate, with you rather than packing them with movers so they don’t get lost. Look through the rest of your things in your current home and determine what you want to keep and what you can leave behind. Temperatures usually only get as low as 40 °F (4 °C) in Los Angeles, so you don’t need to bring many, if any, winter coats, heavy sweatshirts, or other thick clothing. Coordinate with your roommate if you have one to see what they’re bringing so you don’t bring duplicate items. Sell any items that you aren’t bringing with you if you don’t want to save them or if you need additional money to help with your moving costs. If you don’t want to sell or give away items that you’re not moving, then look for a storage unit in your area where you can keep things so they’re safe.Tip: If you’re moving with pets, check that the species is allowed in the state of California. For example, you cannot keep pet hedgehogs or ferrets in the state. If you can’t bring your pet with you, find it a new home before you move.

steps.headline: Hire movers or a shipping company to transport furniture or large items.
steps.description: Look for a reputable moving company and ask them about their shipping rates for your larger items. Once you hire the movers, let them know when you need your items packed up and when you should expect the delivery in LA. The movers will come to your home to pack your things and then ship it for you. It may be easier to sell your old furniture and appliances before you move so you don’t have to pay for shipping them long distances. If you’re moving from overseas, then you may be able to get a shipping container for your items, but they may take weeks to months to arrive and get through United States Customs. You can also rent a moving truck if you want to drive your things to Los Angeles by yourself.

steps.headline: Drive or ship your car to your new place if you want to keep it.
steps.description: If you plan on driving it, pack your car with the most important things to bring with you, such as official documents, computers, or clothes. Plan your route ahead of time so you can figure out where to stop and when you need to fill your car. If you don’t want to drive but still want your car, look for vehicle shipping services and compare their rates to find the best deal. The shipper will transport your car on a flatbed truck and drop it off in LA. Cars registered outside of California need to pass an emissions check before you can register it in the state. You may also sell your car where you live now and put money toward a new car when you first move to Los Angeles.

steps.headline: Put in a change of address before you move to forward your mail.
steps.description: Either go to your local post office or check their website to request a change of address form. Fill out your new address in Los Angeles and submit the form so your mail gets forwarded to your new location. Pay the fee for your change of address online with a credit or debit card to finalize the process. If you don’t have a place to stay immediately, you can set up a temporary change of address online to send your mail to a friend or family member while you’re looking for a place.

steps.headline: Get your driver’s license or ID card from the local DMV.
steps.description: Look online for the application form for a new driver’s license or state ID and fill it out completely to pre-register your information. Search for one of the DMV locations that offers licensing and visit their location while they’re open. Take your application as well as proof of identity, like your Social Security card, birth certificate, and utility bills, with you so you can get your new license. If you haven’t received your license in California before, you may be required to take a multiple-choice test about traffic regulations as well as a behind the wheel driving test. You can schedule an appointment at the DMV online in advance, but the assigned date may be weeks or months later.

steps.headline: Register your vehicle within 20 days of moving if you have one.
steps.description: Take your car into an auto shop that offers smog check services to check the emissions from your car. After you’ve been approved, take your old title, insurance, smog paperwork, and ID with you to the DMV to register your vehicle. Fill out any additional paperwork for your registration so you can legally drive your car in the state. If you do not pass the emissions test, then you may need to get a part retrofitted to your vehicle to make it acceptable.Tip: Some DMV locations don’t offer vehicle registration, so make sure the one you visit has the services you need.

steps.headline: Look for a job that’s near your neighborhood to avoid long commutes.
steps.description: If you don’t already have a job before you move, search online job boards and through temp agencies to see what’s available in your neighborhood. Update your resume with the most current information so potential employers can see your education and work history. Attend any interviews you get and act professional so you can put your best foot forward. You can find jobs outside of your neighborhood, but be sure to check daily commute times to see if you’re able to manage your time and get there each day. As of July 2019, the current minimum wage is $13.25 USD for companies with less than 26 employees and $14.25 for larger businesses. The wage will increase to $15 USD within 1-2 years.

steps.headline: Take public transportation if you don’t want to get caught in traffic as much.
steps.description: While Los Angeles doesn’t have as large of a public transport system as other cities, you can still get around easily using the bus lines or the Metro railway. Look for your nearest bus and Metro stops to see where they are so you can plan traveling and commuting around the city easily. Check the bus and Metro schedules to see when they run and if they’re available to use when you need them. Many 1-way trips on the bus or Metro cost $1.75 USD, but you can buy unlimited monthly passes for about $100 USD. You can also use rideshare apps to get around without driving, but you may still get caught in traffic.

steps.headline: Learn the highway numbers so you don’t get lost.
steps.description: Look at a map of Los Angeles and note all of the major highways that run through it. Refer to the highways by their number rather than their name since that’s how most locals will refer to them. Write down what major roads connect to the highways so you’re able to get around even if you don’t have a GPS. For example, rather than calling I-10 the “Santa Monica Freeway,” you would call it “the 10.”

steps.headline: Make new friends by visiting local events and attending meetups.
steps.description: Check online for free events happening in your area to see what you can attend. Check on local meet-up apps to meet people with similar hobbies or to try something new with a group of people. Be open to the new experiences so you can connect with others and meet friends you can hang out with later. Use social media sites to check what events are happening nearby so you can plan ahead of time. Ask employees at stores and restaurants about cool things in the area to see if they have any information.

steps.headline: Try new restaurants and different cuisines in your area.
steps.description: Los Angeles has a variety of restaurants from many different cuisines, so search for the type of food you want to eat and check what places are in your area and easy to get to. Look at their menus and reviews to determine if you want their food before going to their location. Try different foods you weren’t able to before to expand your tastes. You can also order delivery for many restaurants through apps like Grubhub or Postmates, though it could take a little while depending on the traffic when you order. Certain neighborhoods may have more restaurants from particular cuisines. For example, Little Tokyo has many Japanese restaurants while Chinatown has many Chinese restaurants.

steps.headline: Go hiking to see the Hollywood sign.
steps.description: Los Angeles has miles of hiking trails near the Hollywood sign and the Griffith Observatory that are free for the public to use. Be sure to wear sunscreen while you’re hiking so you don’t get a sunburn, and bring snacks and water with you. Follow the trail signs to the Hollywood sign for a great photo op and workout! If you don’t want to hike, many places also offer horseback tours of the trails. While the hiking trails are free, you may need to pay for parking when you first arrive.

steps.headline: Attend free tapings of TV shows for a chance to be on TV.
steps.description: Many TV shows film in Los Angeles and offer free tickets to be in the studio audience. Look online for audience opportunities near you and choose a show that you’re interested in. While you’re  in the audience, participate actively and pay attention to any special rules or regulations they have. Taping times depend on the length of the show and how many reshoots they need to do, but they can last up to around 4 hours. Many websites offer newsletters so you can learn when new shows are taping.

steps.headline: Visit museums and attractions around Los Angeles to see the art and culture.
steps.description: Los Angeles has many different museums and attractions about history and art, so search online for a few that interest you. Look at what exhibitions they’re currently hosting and check their hours so you know when the best time to visit is. Spend as much time at the museums as you need to learn more about the area and experience LA culture. Some popular attractions in Los Angeles include the Getty Art Museum, the La Brea Tar Pits, the Museum of Natural History, and the LA Zoo.Tip: Many museums and attractions have free days where you can go in without an admission charge.

steps.headline: Spend time at the beach if you want to be near the ocean.
steps.description: The southern Californian coast has multiple beaches to choose from, so look for one that interests you or has nearby attractions so you can spend the day there. Lay in the sun, swim in the ocean, or just relax outdoors to unwind. Be sure to wear sunscreen and reapply it or else you will get burnt. While Venice Beach is popular, it can get crowded with tourists and may not be the most relaxing.
